content: Muhammad Soban Qasim is a student of business analytics student at Monash University. His current interests include working with data to do exploratory data and communicating with data applying a statistical approach.
summary: Muhammad Soban Qasim is a student of business analytics student at Monash University. His current interests include working with data to do exploratory data and communicating with data applying a statistical approach.
title: Muhammad Soban Qasim

content:
吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed neque elit, tristique placerat feugiat ac, facilisis vitae arcu. Proin eget egestas augue. Praesent ut sem nec arcu pellentesque aliquet. Duis dapibus diam vel metus tempus vulputate.
summary: 吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
title: 吳恩達

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
DATA DescriptionThe data set is for the Covid-19 virus affecting all the countries, categorising the cases into confirmed cases, recovered cases and cases that resulted in death. The data set has a lot of limited variables. The data is collected from this link here. Our primary focus for the effected country will be Pakistan.
Why Pakistan?Pakistan, officially the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, is a country in South Asia. It is the world’s fifth-most populous country with a population exceeding 212.2 million. It is the 33rd-largest country by area, spanning 881,913 square kilometres (340,509 square miles).
As the worlds 5th largest populated country, the government of Pakistan had a very different approach in how to handle, and contain the virus.
First the government was hesitent in imposing the lockdown. As reported by this article here.
Then the government with pressure from the opposition international community and the people imposed the lockdown as described in this article.
Here are some important dates according this source.
MethodologyWe will start by filtering the loaded data, the country we want is Pakistan, so we will be filtering that. The first case in Pakistan was reported in February, so let’s get rid of additional dates. Some variables will be taken out, the province variable is empty, coordinates like latitude and longitude make no sense as all the recorded cases are from the same coordinates.
With the lockdown lifted during important events there were a lot of reservations.Some important dates are
13th of March (lockdown imposed)
27th of March (Eid-ul-Fitr, a one day religious festival)
24th of May (loc)
31st of July (Eid-ul-Adha, a three day religions festival)
8th of August (smart lockdown imposed)
14th of August (Independence Day)
{"x":{"url":"/post/2020-09-02-pakcovid19.en_files/figure-html//widgets/widget_Interactive table.html","options":{"xdomain":"*","allowfullscreen":false,"lazyload":false}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}The table is interactive, for users to do their own research with respect to day, month, week of the year, number of cases reported, deaths reported, patients recovered. To identify the surge in numbers, especially after the above mentioned dates.
ConfirmedDeathRecoveredMin. : 1Min. : 0.00Min. : -81st Qu.: 3401st Qu.: 7.001st Qu.: 90Median : 1013Median : 23.00Median : 676Mean : 1730Mean : 36.81Mean : 16413rd Qu.: 27213rd Qu.: 60.003rd Qu.: 2060Max. :12073Max. :178.00Max. :19772Confirmed SummarySummarising Pakistan’s COVID19 cases, in confirmed cases, in a day the least number of cases that were reported is 1 and the maximum number of cases reported in a day are 12,073. The average number of confirmed cases throughout the period have been 1,730. From a range perspective, 1,013 has been the middle for reported cases in a day.
The first quartile (Q1) tells us the middle value from the smallest value which in this case is 1 and the median 1,013. In other words, the first 25% of the cases are reported lower than 340.
The third Quartile (Q3) tells us the middle value from the largest value which in this case is 12,073 and the median 1,013. In other words, the last 25% of the cases are reported higher than 2,721.
Death Summary
Summarising Pakistan’s deaths reported due to COVID19, in deaths reported the least number of deaths reported is 0 on a day, and the maximum number of deaths reported on a day is 178. The average deaths or the mean of deaths reported throughout the period is 36. The mid-range on the number of deaths is at 23.
The first quartile (Q1) tells us the middle value from the smallest value which in this case is 0 and the median 23. In other words, the first 25% of the deaths reported are lower than 7.
The third Quartile (Q3) tells us the middle value from the largest value which in this case is 178 and the median 23. In other words, the last 25% of the cases are reported higher than 60.
Recovered Summary
Summarizing the recovered COVID19 cases in Pakistan. The least number of recovered cases are a bit different, the least number of patients that recovered in a day are -8 which means that the cases reported were untrue, follow this link to get a better understand of the interpretation. The maximum number of recovered cases reported in a day are 19,772. The average recovery of covid19 patients recovered throughout the period is 1,641.
The first quartile (Q1) tells us the middle value from the smallest value which in this case is -8 and the median 676. In other words, the first 25% of the deaths reported are lower than 90.
The third Quartile (Q3) tells us the middle value from the largest value which in this case is 19,772 and the median 676. In other words, the last 25% of the cases are reported higher than 2,060.
summary: DATA DescriptionThe data set is for the Covid-19 virus affecting all the countries, categorising the cases into confirmed cases, recovered cases and cases that resulted in death.
title: Pakistan & CoVID-19

content: Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.   Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
summary: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis posuere tellus ac convallis placerat. Proin tincidunt magna sed ex sollicitudin condimentum.
title: An example preprint / working paper

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides
